{{Infobox person | name = Melissa Haney | birth_date = 1981 | nationality = [[Inuit]], Canadian | occupation = Commercial pilot | known_for = First female Inuit pilot to become captain | home_town = [[Inukjuak]], Quebec }}
'''Melissa Haney''' (born 1981) is an [[Inuit|Inuk]] pilot from [[Quebec]], Canada. She works for [[Air Inuit]], and is noted for being the first female Inuk pilot to reach the rank of captain. In 2017, the Canadian [[Ninety-Nines]] released a postage stamp in commemoration of her achievements.
== Early life == [[File:Inukjuak2014.jpg|left|thumb|179x179px|Haney's hometown of [[Inukjuak]], in northern [[Quebec]]]] Haney was born in 1981.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://canadian99s.com/melissa-haney/|title=MELISSA HANEY|website=canadian99s.com|language=en-US|access-date=2017-11-30}}</ref> She spent her early years in the community of [[Inukjuak]] by [[Hudson Bay]], and as a child, Haney loved going to visit the airport.<ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=http://montreal.ctvnews.ca/first-female-inuk-airline-captain-gets-commemorative-stamp-1.3547198|title=First female Inuk airline captain gets commemorative stamp|date=2017-08-15|work=Montreal|access-date=2017-11-30|language=en-CA}}</ref> Planes were an ordinary form of transportation in Haney's community, necessary for travelling to dental and medical appointments in other communities.<ref name=":0" />
When she was eight, Haney moved south to [[Eastern Townships]] with her mother, who was a teacher. Haney grew up in Eastern Townships, and finished a year of university at [[John Abbott College]] in [[Montreal]]. When she was 19, she heard that [[Air Inuit]] was looking for new employees. Haney decided it sounded interesting and would provide a chance to get closer to her northern childhood community again.<ref name=":3">{{Cite web|url=http://www.nunatsiaqonline.ca/stories/article/65674flying_in_the_face_a_tradition_air_inuit_gets_its_first_inuk_woman_cap/|title=NunatsiaqOnline 2016-03-23: NEWS: Flying in the face of tradition: Air Inuit gets its first Inuk woman captain|website=www.nunatsiaqonline.ca|language=en|access-date=2017-11-30}}</ref>
== Career == In 2001, Haney began working with Air Inuit as a flight attendant.<ref name=":2">{{Cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/north/melisssa-haney-air-inuit-female-pilot-captain-1.4249483|title=Air Inuit's 1st female Inuk captain lands commemorative stamp|work=CBC News|access-date=2017-11-30|language=en}}</ref><ref name=":4">{{Cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/north/first-inuk-woman-captain-air-inuit-1.3778109|title=Pilot becomes first female Inuk captain for Air Inuit|work=CBC News|access-date=2017-11-30|language=en}}</ref> She soon decided she wanted to fly planes herself.<ref name=":1" /> In 2003, Haney took flight lessons in [[Cornwall, Ontario]]. The following year, she completed [[ground school]] courses with Air Inuit.<ref name=":3" /> One of Haney's mentors has been aviator [[Johnny May]], the first Inuk [[bush pilot]] in [[Nunavik]].<ref name=":0" /> In 2004, Haney began flying [[Twin Otter]] aircraft for Air Inuit.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.iwoaw.org/symposium/speaker/melissa-haney/|title=Melissa Haney|last=Team|first=iWOAW|date=2017-04-04|work=Institute for Women Of Aviation Worldwide (iWOAW) Symposium|access-date=2017-11-30|language=en-US}}</ref> [[File:Air Inuit (10111289846).jpg|thumb|179x179px|An [[Air Inuit]] Dash 8-300Q aircraft]] In the summer of 2016, Haney was promoted to captain. When she flew back to Inukjuak in September, several hundred people from her community gathered to meet her at the airport.<ref name=":4" /><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.nunatsiaqonline.ca/stories/article/65674nunavik_community_celebrates_its_hometown_hero/|title=NunatsiaqOnline 2016-09-26: NEWS: Nunavik town celebrates a high-flying hometown hero|website=www.nunatsiaqonline.ca|language=en|access-date=2017-11-30}}</ref>
She now regularly flies a [[Dash 8 Combi-300]], making tight landings on runways that are often just barely long enough for her aircraft.<ref name=":0" />
On August 15, 2017, the Canadian [[Ninety-Nines]] released a commemorative postage stamp featuring Haney.<ref name=":2" /><ref name=":1" /><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.nunatsiaqonline.ca/stories/article/65674air_inuit_pilot_featured_on_new_postage_stamp/|title=NunatsiaqOnline 2017-08-16: NEWS: Air Inuit pilot featured on new postage stamp|website=www.nunatsiaqonline.ca|language=en|access-date=2017-11-30}}</ref> Speaking to reporters, the president of Air Inuit said that Haney "was a role model for all people in Nunavik, whether they're women, whether they're men.‚Äù<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.ctvnews.ca/canada/air-inuit-s-first-female-inuk-captain-honoured-in-quebec-1.3547507|title=Air Inuit's first female Inuk captain honoured in Quebec|date=2017-08-15|work=CTVNews|access-date=2017-11-30|language=en-CA}}</ref>
== Personal life == Haney is married to another Air Inuit captain named Pierre-Olivier, and the couple has two children.<ref name=":0" />
